question: Which statement best describes your investment approach?
choices_list: a. “I only invest if I have a guarantee of getting back at least my original investment.” – I take minimal risk and accept lower returns
b. “I’m willing to take a small amount of risk to earn slightly more than bank deposit rates.” – Conservative: minor risks for modest returns
c. “I seek steady long-term growth and can handle some short-term fluctuations.” – Moderate risk for balanced growth
d. “I aim for strong long-term growth and understand this means larger short-term swings in value.” – Growth-oriented: sizable risk for higher returns
e. “I want to maximize returns and am very comfortable with high volatility and potential losses.” – Highly aggressive in pursuit of returns

question: How long do you plan to invest these funds before you will need to withdraw a significant portion?
choices_list: a. Short-term (under 3 years): I may need the money very soon
b. 2–5 years: I have a fairly short investment horizon
c. 6–10 years: Medium-term horizon
d. 11–20 years: Long-term, ample time to ride out ups and downs
e. Over 20 years: Very long-term; no need for funds in the foreseeable future

question: If your investment portfolio dropped 20% in value within a year, what would you most likely do? (Assume the decline is market-wide)
choices_list: a. Sell all investments to prevent further losses – I cannot tolerate this loss
b. Sell a portion and shift to safer assets – I’d reduce risk if losses continue
c. Hold the investments but feel very concerned – I’d avoid selling immediately, though uneasy
d. Hold and stay the course confidently – I would not panic and stick to my long-term plan
e. Buy more at the lower prices – I see a downturn as an opportunity and can accept short-term loss

question: Which statement best reflects your attitude toward the trade-off between potential returns and potential losses?
choices_list: a. “Avoiding loss is my top priority; I accept much lower returns to keep my money safe.”
b. “I’m more concerned with losses than gains; I prefer to minimize risk even at the cost of some growth.”
c. “I balance my concern about losses and gains equally; a moderate risk/return trade-off is fine.”
d. “I’m more focused on returns; I can tolerate some losses in pursuit of higher growth.”
e. “I prioritize maximizing returns; potential losses are of little concern to me.”

question: What is the largest decline in your portfolio’s value you could comfortably tolerate in a single year?
choices_list: a. Less than 5% loss – even a small drop would be uncomfortable
b. 5–10% loss – I could endure a modest decline
c. 10–15% loss – a moderate drop is acceptable for me
d. 15–25% loss – I’m fairly comfortable with significant volatility
e. Over 25% loss – I can tolerate very large swings in value

question: Which of the following investment portfolios would you feel most comfortable with for the majority of your money?
choices_list: a. Very conservative: Mostly cash or guaranteed products (e.g. deposits, government bonds) – minimal risk/return
b. Conservative: Portfolio of primarily high-quality bonds and a small portion of stocks – low risk, low-medium returns
c. Balanced: Mixed portfolio (~50% stocks and 50% bonds) – moderate risk and returns
d. Growth: Portfolio mostly in stocks (e.g. 80% stocks/20% bonds) – higher risk, higher potential returns
e. Aggressive: Nearly all in stocks or risky assets (e.g. emerging markets) – maximum risk for maximum return

question: Which statement best describes the type of investments you currently hold or are most familiar with?
choices_list: a. Very low-risk only: I stick to bank savings, fixed deposits, or guaranteed funds
b. Mostly conservative: I have invested in bonds or bond funds, but little in stocks
c. Balanced exposure: I hold a mix of stock and bond investments
d. Mostly stocks: I’m comfortable investing in stocks, equity funds, or similar growth-oriented assets
e. High-risk instruments: I have experience with very volatile or speculative investments (e.g. small-cap stocks, commodities)
